Thanks, Simon. My comments today will build on themes discussed at our recently held Analyst Day in New York. We’ll discuss our performance within the framework of our unmatched foundation, world-class execution and our winning strategy.
First, we are pleased with our financial execution and discipline. Our revenue in the second quarter was $146.5 million, a sequential increase of 3%, and at the high end of the guidance we provided during our first quarter earnings call. On a sequential basis, revenue from Host Products grew 2%, revenue from Network Products grew 6% and revenue from Silicon Products grew 5%.
We are also very pleased to have achieved an operating margin of 30.2%, and a net profit margin of 25% during the second quarter, driven by higher than expected gross margin and lower than expected operating expenses.
During the second quarter, our net income per diluted share was $0.34, higher than our forecasted range of $0.29 to $0.32, provided during our first quarter earning conference call. At our recent Analyst Day, we detailed our Adaptive Convergence strategy and offered proof points to the strategy’s yielding winning results. We want to share some of the highlights and accomplishments that we think were clear indicator of the progress we have made in expanding our market opportunities as well as keeping proper focus on our traditional markets.
Our early investments in convergence and our time-to-market advantage for converged products have resulted in leadership positions in two important markets. On August 12, we announced that according to new data published by the Dell’Oro Group in its Q2 2010 SAN Adapter Report, QLogic was the leader of the 10-gig converged network adapter market with over 58% revenue market share for calendar Q2 2010.This represents a lead over our nearest competitor of 18.5 percentage points. This percentage of share split slightly exceeds our Fibre Channel SAN adapter market leadership, also reinforcing the power and leverage of our Fibre Channel market position.
On August 23, we announced that according to more new data published by the Dell’Oro Group in its Q2 2010 Network Adapter Report, QLogic took over the number two position for the first time with 15.7% revenue share in the 10-gig adapter market, second only to Intel for the quarter, and tied for number one imports. QLogic was the only company to have gained market share for five consecutive quarters. This market is a significant incremental expansion opportunity for QLogic.
Further strengthening our offering in converged networking, we recently launched the industry’s first third generation 10-gig converged networking portfolio named 3GCNA. Based on our industry leading and broadly deployed Network Plus Architecture, the portfolio features a trio of new products, including our 8200 Series 10-gig converged network adapters, our 3200 Series 10-gig intelligent Ethernet adapters, and our converged LAN-on-motherboard solution. These products feature a number of industry-first for the converged networking market, including the first product with the ability to run Fibre Channel over Ethernet, iSCSI, and Ethernet traffic concurrently. This is also the first product to perform switch-agnostic VM-to-VM communications within physical machines and the first product to deploy quad 1-gig and dual 10-gig ports from a single chip using our advanced FlexLOM technology.
The 3GCNA portfolio is the first launch under QLogic’s recently unveiled Adaptive Convergence strategy. This strategy builds on the success of the company’s leadership positions and introduce four key flexible business enabling interconnect capabilities; ConvergeFlex being Concurrent Protocol Processing Services; VMflex being Advanced Virtualization Services; FlexOffload being Multiple Protocol Offload Services, and SecureFlex being Data Security Services. The new products address the increasing complex requirements of virtualized data centers, cloud service providers, and the converged enterprise. All of these environments will require 10-gig line rate throughput for virtualized data and storage traffic, support from concurrent Ethernet, FCoE and iSCSI, and low CPU utilization to allow for a high mobility of VMs.
During the quarter, we saw further success with our converged switching technology. Our Bullet ASIC is now shipping and HP-3Com recently announced 5820 Series top-of-rack products. Using our Bullet ASIC, HP-3Com can take advantage of our highly innovative flex port technology that enables ports to be dynamically allocated to support Fibre Channel, iSCSI, or FCoE data. This product further strengthens our converged product portfolio with HP.
Our InfiniBand momentum continued in the HPC space with the deployment of end-to-end QLogic TrueScale products at Lawrence Livermore National Labs. This high profile installation of a Dell supercomputing systems code-named Sierra is expected to rank in the top 20 of the world’s most powerful supercomputers on the top 500 list. InfiniBand is the fastest growing server interconnect technology in the top 500. Our traditional storage area networking markets continue to be a very important business for us. We’ll continue investment in products for the SAN market for many years to come.
Late last month, we announced our full support for the 16-gig Fibre Channel standards, which was ratified by the ANSI Technical Committee and announced by the Fibre Channel Industry Association. We’ll be offering a complete portfolio of 16-gig Fibre Channel host and switch products, providing SAN users a doubling of the bandwidth with backward compatibility to 8-gig and 4-gig products. Maintaining and growing our market share in Fibre Channel adapters continues to be an important priority for us. The media 2010 check point in the Fibre Channel adapter market share is encouraging. Based on the most recently published Dell’Oro data, our revenue market share in Fibre Channel adapters for the first half of calendar 2010 is substantially the same as our full year 2009 share.
Our market share remains at just over 54%, while our closest competitor has lost over a point. In summary, we have an unmatched foundation for success, world-class execution, and winning strategy. While it is clear to us that the recovery is weaker than had been expected.
